channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Saudis and Extremism: ‘Both the Arsonists and the Firefighters’
item.media:description: Muslim pilgrims surrounding the Kaaba, the black cube at the center of Islam’s holiest mosque in Mecca, in 2003. The Saudis’ export of Wahhabism has special cachet because the country is the birthplace of the Prophet Muhammad.
item.description: Critics see Saudi Arabia’s export of a rigid strain of Islam as contributing to terrorism, but the kingdom’s influence depends greatly on local conditions.
item.dc:creator: SCOTT SHANE
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: The Interpreter: Syria’s Paradox: Why the War Only Ever Seems to Get Worse
item.media:description: A poster of President Bashar al-Assad on a destroyed shopping mall in Homs in 2014. Despite many offensives, peace conferences and foreign interventions, Syria’s civil war shows no sign of ending.
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.description: Experts on civil wars say there are several reasons Syria is “a really, really tough case” that defies historical parallels.
item.dc:creator: MAX FISHER
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Besieged Town of Daraya Agrees to Surrender to Syrian Government
item.media:description: A bombing killed 14 on Thursday in Aleppo, Syria. To the south, a four-year siege ended in rebel-held Daraya as the town struck a deal with the government.
item.description: As the rebel-held town planned for the evacuation of its 8,000 remaining residents, a bombing that killed 14 in Aleppo served as a reminder of what Daraya had faced for four years.
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD and HWAIDA SAAD

item.title: Hopes Dim for Survivors of Italy Quake; Death Toll Stands at 267
item.media:description: Emergency workers in Amatrice, Italy, on Thursday searching the rubble of a building that was destroyed by the earthquake.
item.description: In the devastated town of Amatrice, a row of gray tents has been serving as a makeshift morgue.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

item.title: News Analysis: ‘Brexit’ Vote Feeds Scotland’s Alienation
item.media:description: Thousands took part in the “All Under One Banner” march for Scottish independence last month in Glasgow.
item.media:credit: Jane Barlow/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.description: The vote for a British exit from the European Union felt crushing to the Scots. But despite everything, another independence referendum feels far away.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Court Overturns ‘Burkini’ Ban in French Town
item.media:description: A woman wore a burkini to a demonstration in London on Thursday against measures in France banning the full-body swimwear at beaches.
item.description: The court ruled that the prohibition in Villeneuve-Loubet violated civil liberties, in a warning that could affect other communities that have banned the swimwear.
item.dc:creator: AURELIEN BREEDEN and LILIA BLAISE

item.title: Brazilian Police Recommend Charges Against Ryan Lochte
item.media:description: Ryan Lochte won a gold medal at the Summer Games in Rio de Janeiro. He could now face criminal charges in Brazil for providing false testimony.
item.description: The American swimmer could be charged with giving false testimony in connection with claims that he was robbed at gunpoint during the Rio Olympics.
item.dc:creator: VINOD SREEHARSHA

item.title: Ex-Military Officers Convicted of Human Rights Crimes During Argentina Dictatorship
item.media:description: Nora de Cortinas, president of the Argentine group Mothers of the Plaza de Mayo, attended the trial of former military officers in Buenos Aires in May.
item.description: The 38 former officials were tried in the kidnapping, torture and killing of several hundred victims under a government in power from 1976 to 1983.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN GILBERT
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

item.title: Aching for Peace, but Also Justice, Colombians Weigh Deal With FARC
item.media:description: FARC guerrillas greeting local farmers in May. In many parts of Colombia, civilians know no law and order other than from the rebel group.
item.description: The fate of a deal to end Colombia’s long war is in the hands of voters who nurse deep wounds and have ample reason to be suspicious of the rebels’ promises.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS CASEY

item.title: The Saturday Profile: A Critic’s Lonely Quest: Revealing the Whole Truth About Mother Teresa
item.media:description: Dr. Aroup Chatterjee, a London-based physician, published “Mother Teresa: The Final Verdict” in 2003, which cataloged evidence that the Missionaries of Charity ran inadequate facilities and often offered little comfort to those it was trying to help.
item.media:credit: Ko Sasaki for The New York Times
item.description: Dr. Aroup Chatterjee has spent hundreds of hours researching the soon-to-be saint. “I just thought that this myth had to be challenged,” he said.
item.dc:creator: KAI SCHULTZ

item.title: Indian Court Orders Haji Ali Tomb to Give Women Full Access
item.media:description: Visitors at the Haji Ali tomb, a popular Muslim religious destination, in Mumbai last year.
item.description: Balancing religious and civil rights, the Bombay High Court overturned a ban excluding Muslim women from the inner sanctum of the tomb in Mumbai.
item.dc:creator: GEETA ANAND and SUHASINI RAJ
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: ‘No One Is Safe’: Zimbabwe Threatens to Seize Farms of Party Defectors
item.media:description: Agrippah Mutambara at his farm on the outskirts of Bindura, Zimbabwe. Like dozens of political figures who have fallen out of favor, he is facing the seizure of his farm.
item.description: In a nation where land is used as a tool of control, many former officials who were beneficiaries of seizures of white-owned farms now find themselves potential victims.
item.dc:creator: NORIMITSU ONISHI

item.title: Gabon’s Leader Gives Elephants Free Rein. Rural Voters Don’t Forget.
item.media:description: Entering a shower near open sewage in the Cei neighborhood of Libreville, Gabon, a nation with glaring inequalities between rich and poor.
item.media:credit: Uriel Sinai for The New York Times
item.description: Though he is expected to win re-election, Ali Bongo Ondimba, who has prioritized protecting wildlife, faces criticism that he worries more about animals than his nation’s people.
item.dc:creator: DIONNE SEARCEY

item.title: Bolivia Says Official Sent to Negotiate With Miners Is Killed
item.media:description: Demanding that the country’s mining laws be changed, miners blocked a highway on Thursday in Panduro, south of La Paz, Bolivia.
item.description: After blocking a highway, members of a miners’ cooperative kidnapped, tortured and killed Rodolfo Illanes, the deputy interior minister, the authorities said.
item.dc:creator: MONICA MACHICAO and NICHOLAS CASEY

item.title: Police in Zimbabwe Hit Protesters With Batons, Tear Gas and Water Cannons
item.media:description: Opposition supporters clashed with the police on Friday in Harare. Officers used tear gas and water cannons to disperse hundreds protesting against the government.
item.description: Despite a last-minute court order allowing a demonstration, the police used violent means to disperse hundreds protesting against President Robert Mugabe.
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY MOYO and NORIMITSU ONISHI

item.title: Philippine Government and Communist Rebels Extend Cease-Fire
item.description: The two sides, who have been fighting for decades, also agreed to return to peace talks in October.
item.dc:creator: FELIPE VILLAMOR

item.title: Prosecutors in Oscar Pistorius Case Lose Bid to Appeal 6-Year Sentence
item.media:description: Oscar Pistorius at the London Paralympics in 2012.
item.description: Mr. Pistorius was convicted of the 2013 murder of his girlfriend, but last month he received a sentence more lenient than many observers had expected.
item.dc:creator: SEWELL CHAN

item.title: Hungarian PM Orban Urges EU to Build an Army of Its Own
item.description: Hungary's prime minister urged the European Union on Friday to make security a priority and build an army of its own.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Monthlong Ordeal for Hiker in New Zealand: Partner’s Death and Bitter Cold
item.media:description: The remote area on the South Island of New Zealand where a rescue operation was carried out to recover the body of Ondrej Petr, Ms. Pizova’s boyfriend.
item.media:credit: New Zealand Police, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: After her partner plunged to his death on their hike, a Czech woman spent a month alone in a hut on a famed New Zealand trail.
item.dc:creator: BRETT COLE

item.title: Sinosphere: Ai Weiwei Planned to Sculpt a ‘Redline.’ Chinese Censors Say He Crossed One.
item.media:description: A photograph provided by Ai Weiwei shows the red line drawn by organizers of an exhibit at the Yinchuan Museum of Contemporary Art to indicate where Mr. Ai could place his art. It inspired his plan for a work titled “Redline.”
item.description: An invitation to exhibit next month at a show in northwest China was withdrawn, leading the outspoken Mr. Ai to denounce efforts to limit free expression.
item.dc:creator: JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ

item.title: At Least 7 Dead as Shabab Militants Attack Restaurant in Somali Capital
item.description: The Shabab have carried out a series of deadly attacks in Somalia to try to topple the Western-backed government of the country.
item.dc:creator: HUSSEIN MOHAMED

item.title: VW to Pay $1.2 Billion to U.S. Dealers Hurt by Diesel Scandal
item.media:description: Volkswagen fell into turmoil last September after admitting it had equipped nearly 600,000 diesel models sold in the United States with “defeat device” software.
item.media:credit: Kieran Kesner for The New York Times
item.description: The settlement, still subject to a federal judge’s approval, is meant to address lost sales and the declining value of Volkswagen dealerships.
item.dc:creator: NEAL E. BOUDETTE

item.title: Some Villages in Italy May Never Recover From Earthquake
item.media:description: Rescuers on Thursday in Pescara del Tronto, Italy, where about five houses were left standing.
item.description: For some of the smallest mountain towns, where homes have been leveled and lives lost, displaced residents face the possible elimination of the towns themselves.
item.dc:creator: GAIA PIANIGIANI

item.title: Tensions Rise Between Iran and U.S. in Persian Gulf
item.description: American military officials reported four potentially dangerous episodes in the Gulf this week between United States and Iranian naval vessels.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Russia, Fuming at Paralympics Ban, Steps Up Campaign Against Whistle-Blower
item.media:description: A Moscow court has ordered the seizure of property belonging to Dr. Grigory Rodchenkov, the former director of Russia’s antidoping laboratory.
item.media:credit: Emily Berl for The New York Times
item.description: The authorities are hounding the whistle-blower doctor in the doping scandal and spinning elaborate conspiracy theories — anything but admitting their own misdeeds.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW HIGGINS

item.title: Kenya Disbands Olympic Committee, Citing Disorganization
item.media:description: Members of the Kenya delegation during the opening ceremony of the Rio Games.
item.description: Kenya’s stellar performance in Rio was marred by a doping scandal, poor treatment of athletes and missing athletic gear.
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY GETTLEMAN

item.title: Brazil’s Next Must-Watch Event: A President’s Impeachment Trial
item.media:description: President Dilma Rousseff in São Paulo, Brazil, on Tuesday. She was suspended in May and is facing charges of manipulating the federal budget in an attempt to conceal the country’s economic problems.
item.description: The Senate began its impeachment trial of President Dilma Rousseff, who was suspended in May facing charges of manipulating the federal budget.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO

item.title: World Bank President Jim Yong Kim Is Nominated for a Second Term
item.media:description: Jim Yong Kim in June.
item.description: Despite persistent complaints from staff members about Jim Yong Kim’s leadership, the United States has tapped him for another five-year term.
item.dc:creator: JACKIE CALMES

item.title: U.N. Rights Official Calls for Inquiry Into Abuses in Yemen Conflict
item.media:description: The site of a Saudi-led air strike in Sanaa, Yemen. At least 3,799 civilians have been killed and 6,711 injured since fighting in the country flared in March 2015.
item.description: The move, accompanying a report by investigators, revives a proposal that Saudi Arabia and the Yemeni government it supports have fiercely resisted.
item.dc:creator: NICK CUMMING-BRUCE
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: With Operation in Syria, Erdogan Shows His New Power Over Turkey’s Military
item.media:description: Turkish tanks made their way toward the Syrian town of Jarabulus on Thursday.
item.description: The failed coup in Turkey and the purge that followed appear to have enhanced President Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s control of the military.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Utracán Journal: On Argentina Plains, Hunters Feel Besieged by Critics ‘Made of Asphalt’
item.media:description: Daniel Briguez, second from left, during a morning hunt last month in La Pampa Province, Argentina. With Mr. Briguez, and his mastiffs, were his son Franco Briguez, left, Hugo Javier Alfonso, center, and Jorge Fetter and his son.
item.description: Threats to a hunting tradition emerge as animal rights activists, buoyed by their growing clout, say the time has come to put an end to boar hunts.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN GILBERT
item.category: Association of Officials and Lawyers for Animal Rights

item.title: North Korea Unveils Netflix-Like Service With Propaganda on Demand
item.media:description: Very few North Koreans are permitted access to the internet.
item.description: Manbang, as it is called, will allow people to watch their country “make a leap forward every day, every hour,” Korean Central Television said.
item.dc:creator: PATRICK BOEHLER and CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Driver in Japan Playing Pokémon Go Kills Pedestrian
item.media:description: People playing Pokémon Go at a park in Tokyo in July. More than 10 million people in Japan downloaded the game on the day it debuted last month.
item.description: The death of a 72-year-old woman struck by a cargo van is the first in Japan, and it follows numerous mishaps around the world as the game became popular.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN SOBLE

item.title: Sonia Rykiel, Fashion Designer for the ‘Fragile, but Strong,’ Dies at 86
item.media:description: Sonia Rykiel, right, and her daughter Nathalie Rykiel, artistic director for her mother’s fashion house, in 2008. In a fashion world often seen as a fantasyland of beautiful people and expensive, impractical clothing, she had always been a rebel.
item.description: Based in Paris, she made fashions for women, like herself, who were proud of their pregnancies, sophisticated about sex and too busy to fuss over the latest fads.
item.dc:creator: ROBERT D. McFADDEN

item.title: Attack at University in Kabul Shatters a Sense of Freedom
item.description: Men with rifles and grenades put the American University of Afghanistan, an oasis from violence, through an ordeal that lasted nearly 10 hours and claimed 13 lives.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL, MOHAMAD FAHIM ABED and ZAHRA NADER

item.title: What in the World: Shh. It’s Naptime at Ikea in China.
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrie for The New York Times
item.description: At Ikea’s 21 stores in China, shoppers (and those simply looking for climate-controlled shut-eye) have no qualms about getting comfortable on the display furniture.
item.dc:creator: DAN LEVIN

item.title: What in the World: Holy Water for Pilgrims, via the Mail
item.media:credit: Illustration by Lia Kantrowitz; Photos by saiko3p and Evgeny Karandaev/Shutterstock
item.description: The Indian postal service is using its offices to deliver holy water from the Ganges River, which is usually collected after a barefoot pilgrimage.
item.dc:creator: KAUSHIK SWAMINATHAN

item.title: Opinion: At the Beach in My Burkini
item.description: I dreaded wearing it in middle school. Not anymore.
item.dc:creator: ROMAISSAA BENZIZOUNE

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Why I Go to Aleppo
item.media:description: Waiting to receive treatment at a makeshift hospital in a rebel-held neighborhood of Aleppo, Syria, last month.
item.description: My first taste of volunteering as a medic was on 9/11. Today, trying to save lives in Syria is my cause.
item.dc:creator: SAMER ATTAR

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: America’s Retreat and the Agony of Aleppo
item.description: American power has lost credibility, moral conviction has eroded, and a Syrian city bleeds to death.
item.dc:creator: ROGER COHEN

item.title: Photo Editors’ Notebook: What Makes the Image of Omran Daqneesh Extraordinary?
item.media:description: The front page of The New York Times on August 19 featured a photograph by Mahmoud Raslan of a 5-year-old boy who was rescued after an airstrike in Aleppo, Syria.
item.description: “It’s a difficult question for even the most seasoned photo editor to answer.”
item.dc:creator: CRAIG ALLEN

item.title: Devanampattinam Journal: Mortal to Divine and Back: India’s Transgender Goddesses
item.description: During the 10-day Hindu festival Mayana Kollai, the troubles of transgender women are distant as they transform into the deities they worship and are revered by villagers.
item.dc:creator: Photographs by CANDACE FEIT

item.title: Notebook: How Many Guns Did the U.S. Lose Track of in Iraq and Afghanistan? Hundreds of Thousands.
item.media:description: Iraqi soldiers after receiving new rifles from U.S. forces in Baghdad in May 2007.
item.description: A new study shows how the American military failed at the soldier’s most basic responsibility: keeping track of firearms.
item.dc:creator: C. J. CHIVERS
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Talking to Terrorists
item.media:description: Harry Sarfo, a former Islamic State fighter from Germany, inside the maximum-security prison in Bremen where he is serving a three-year sentence on terrorism charges.
item.media:credit: Gordon Welters for The New York Times
item.description: For once, the conversation wasn’t via social media, and the name the Islamic State defector used was the one on his birth certificate.
item.dc:creator: RUKMINI CALLIMACHI
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: At the Front in a Scarred Falluja
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.description: Bryan Denton, a photographer who works for The New York Times and is based in Beirut, Lebanon, gives his account of covering Iraqi forces’ recapture of Falluja from the Islamic State.
item.dc:creator: BRYAN DENTON
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
